equations.latex: \begin{aligned}&TG + CH_{3}OH \xrightleftharpoons[k_{2}]{k_{1}} DG + R_{1}COOCH_{3}\\&DG + CH_{3}OH \xrightleftharpoons[k_{4}]{k_{3}} MG + R_{2}COOCH_{3}\\&MG + CH_{3}OH \xrightleftharpoons[k_{6}]{k_{5}} GL + R_{3}COOCH_{3}\\&\text{Overall: }TG + 3CH_{3}OH \rightleftharpoons 3RCOOCH_{3} + GL\end{aligned}
equations.description: Reaction scheme for the transesterification of triglycerides (TG) through diglycerides (DG) and monoglycerides (MG) to glycerol (GL) producing methyl esters (RCOOCH₃) in three reversible steps.
Ordinary differential equation for the rate of change of triglyceride concentration, combining its consumption and formation by the first reversible reaction.
ODE for diglyceride concentration dynamics, accounting for its formation from TG and its consumption to MG.
ODE for monoglyceride concentration, reflecting its production from DG and subsequent consumption toward glycerol.
ODE for methanol consumption and methyl ester formation, combining contributions from all transesterification steps.
Mass balance relation showing that alcohol consumption rate is the negative of methyl ester formation rate.
ODE for glycerol production rate from monoglyceride in the final transesterification step.
Arrhenius-type expression relating the reaction rate constant k_i to temperature T, with pre-exponential factor a_i and activation parameter b_i.
Objective function for maximization, defined as the weighted sum of component concentrations at the final time according to the maximum principle.
Generalized form of the state equations describing temporal evolution of each component concentration under temperature control.
Hamiltonian function combining adjoint variables z_i with the right-hand sides F_i of the state ODEs in the Pontryagin maximum principle.
Adjoint (co-state) differential equations giving the dynamics of z_i based on sensitivities of the state dynamics.
Explicit form of the Hamiltonian as a sum over the six system states, used in deriving optimality conditions.
Time–optimal control objective reformulated as minimization of the integral over the inverse rate of change of ester concentration, yielding final time t_f.
Constraint relating differential changes of any component concentration to those of the ester concentration for the time–optimal formulation.
Iterative update rule for the reactor temperature profile, moving along the steepest ascent direction of the Hamiltonian gradient with step M.
Expression for the total derivative of the Hamiltonian with respect to temperature, involving sensitivities θ_i and φ_i.
Definition of θ_i as the sensitivity of component concentrations to temperature changes.
Definition of φ_i as the sensitivity of the adjoint variables to temperature variations.
Mixed derivative property showing equivalence of differentiating the state rate with respect to temperature and differentiation of concentration sensitivity over time.
